Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical and Experimental Design of Multifunctional Plasmonic Electrodes for Polymer-Based Optoelectronics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: Plasmonic near-fields can be used to increase exciton generation or emission rate in organic conjugated polymer semiconductor materials. However, to incorporate plasmonic effects in conjugated polymer-based optoelectronic devices, it is important to control and stabilize the surface electronic properties of the plasmonic structure. The goal of this project is to develop design principles for multifunctional plasmonic electrodes that are: (1) optically active; (2) efficient at charge carrier collection/injection; (3) stable under ambient conditions; and (4) compatible with scalable nanofabrication routes for organic polymer optoelectronic applications. The plasmonic electrodes consist of vertically-oriented metal nanorod arrays that support surface plasmons and that are either uncoated or have an ultra-thin (native) metal oxide coating to tune the surface work function, eliminate the need for additional hole transport/electron blocking layers, mitigate exciton quenching, and improve performance lifetime in ambient conditions.

Non-technical Description: The electrodes developed in this project, that provide light management capabilities and that exhibit stable, controllable surface electronic properties, are expected to enable both more efficient and more durable organic polymer-based optoelectronic devices, making them more viable for energy efficiency and generation applications. The project activities also combine interdisciplinary research in materials science and engineering, and chemistry with education by enabling undergraduate students from local and state programs (such as Rutgers Research in Science and Engineering program, Rutgers' Green Energy Technology REU program and the New Jersey Governor's School of Engineering and Technology) to work alongside graduate researchers on the goals of the project. Additional project activities continue to support, encourage and maintain diversity in the research team and in the broader scientific community; and incorporate participation in high-school enrichment as part of Rutgers' outreach programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Semiconducting polymers are of interest as the active layer material in ultrathin, lightweight, wearable and low-cost optoelectronic devices, such as organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), organic solar cells and organic lasers. In polymer optoelectronic devices, the active layer thickness is well below the wavelength of visible light. Therefore, for efficient and durable polymer optoelectronic devices, controlling light absorption and emission in thin polymer layers requires light-management in nanoscale volumes, as well as efficient and stable charge injection and collection. This project proposed the use of multifunctional plasmonic electrodes to enable both more efficient and more durable semiconducting polymer-based optoelectronic devices. The goal of this project was to develop design principles for multifunctional electrodes that are: (1) optically active? (2) efficient at charge carrier collection/injection? (3) stable under ambient conditions and (4) compatible with scalable nanofabrication routes. To achieve the project goal, the following research tasks were carried out. (1) Theoretical prediction of both the optical and electronic performance of plasmonic electrodes (with and without surface oxides) in both conventional and inverted conjugated polymer optoelectronic devices. (2) Fabrication of silver plasmonic electrodes, and development and application of native oxides to the electrode surface. (3) Experimental comparison of the optical and electronic performance and stability of plasmonic electrodes with and without the presence of conjugated polymer layer coatings (specifically, measurement of plasmonic effects, and charge injection/collection barriers with and without electrode surface oxides).

The main scientific results of the research were design principles that have had an impact on the plasmonics, thin-film optoelectronics and metamaterials communities through greater understanding of molecular semiconductor-plasmonic electrode interactions and through an understanding of how to control light trapping and charge collection using plasmonic electrodes. In addition to the design principles, through the project work, the phenomenon of absorption-induced scattering was identified for the first time and was shown to arise from electromagnetic coupling between plasmonic light scattering structures and excitonic absorbing materials. Furthermore, we found that the crystallinity of the semiconducting polymer film is an importance factor that needs to be controlled for effective light management using plasmonic electrodes. For improved light extraction in light-emitting applications, amorphous semiconducting polymers are more appropriate; for improved light trapping, semiconducting polymers with high degrees of crystallinity are more effective.

The design principles for multifunction plasmonic electrodes that were developed in this project have been disseminated widely through publication of 13 peer-reviewed research papers. Additionally, the project has resulted in one issued US patent, as well as numerous invited and contributed scientific presentations at national conferences and academic institutions. In addition to the new scientific knowledge generated from this project, 18 graduate and undergraduate researchers and four high-school students took part in the project activities with balanced representation from both male and female researchers (50 % male and 50 % female). This project has impacted the careers of many of it’s participants. Most have gone on to obtain jobs in optoelectronic materials-related industries (in both established companies and start-up companies in the US), and numerous other participants are now conducting materials- or photonics-related research in prominent academic and research institutions.
